awd_titl_txt: Temporal Multimode Transformations for Quantum Information Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum information science and technology (QIST) is a rapidly evolving field of interdisciplinary research that aims to harness the behavior of quantum systems to enable new capabilities for a range of applications including computation, communications, and sensing. A variety of physical systems are being explored for their potential to encode and manipulate quantum bits (qubits), each of which presents different advantages and challenges. Within QIST, light plays an important role in the transport and extraction of quantum information. To date most approaches to encoding quantum information in light fields has focused on polarization and spatial profile of light beams, which are not compatible with optical fiber networks that will form the backbone of a future quantum Internet. In this project the group will develop an experimental platform to encode quantum information in temporal modes of quantum light, where the temporal shape and color of a photon, a light ‘particle,’ carries information. Quantum applications enabled by temporal mode encoding include linear optics quantum computing, quantum communications, sensing, and simulations. Beyond the scientific and technological impacts, this project will contribute to a quantum-ready workforce through training of graduate and undergraduate students. 

This project will develop methods to control and measure pulses of light at the single-photon level and its application to perform targeted operations for quantum information applications. Common approaches to shape optical laser pulses, which employ filtering or amplification, are not compatible with quantum light. To address the temporal modes of light thus requires unitary (phase only) transformations that modify the spectral and temporal phase of the light pulses. For quantum applications most efforts have focused on nonlinear optical means for pulse control. Here the group will use linear-optical methods with electro-optic temporal phase modulation and dispersive spectral phase. The overarching research goal is the implementation of unitary transformations on temporal modes. The proposed approach is to realize such temporal mode transformations by the sequential application of temporal phase modulation and spectral dispersion using off-the-shelf components. To overcome challenges in timing instability that arise in the application of temporal phase using electro-optic modulators, the radio-frequency driving field will be directly generated from the optical pulses that generate the single photons to be manipulated. To verify that the targeted temporal mode transformations are experimentally implemented, an approach to characterize the transformations – a technique known as quantum process tomography – based upon spectral interferometry will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to manipulate and measure quantum information in an optical field has numerous applications in quantum information science and technology including all-optical quantum computing, quantum networking and quantum-enhanced sensing. In this context, the aim of this project was to develop an experimental platform to encode quantum information in temporal modes of light, where temporal shape and color of a single photon, or “light particle,” carries quantum information. During the project we developed detailed theoretical and experimental methods to study temporal mode transformations capable of converting a set of multiple, independent input pulses to a targeted set of distinct output pulses as a method of encoding quantum information and means to characterize such temporal mode transformations. This led to discoveries of practical limits to such techniques that will inform future applications. 

Intellectual Merit: Controlling the temporal and spectral shape of an optical pulse – whether the pulse comes from a laser or single-photon source – plays a central role in quantum and classical applications such as nonlinear microscopy, laser eye surgery, deep-space optical communications and the Internet. Here we developed an approach to perform temporal mode transformations through the application of a sequence of time- and frequency-dependent phases to an input pulse, which ensures there is no loss, and thus no degradation of the quantum signal. To characterize the temporal mode transformations implemented we advanced an interferometric measurement technique within the project.   

The specific approach taken here to produce the temporal and spectral phases needed to realize a targeted temporal mode transformation utilized electro-optic phase modulation, where a time-varying radio-frequency (RF) signal imposes a time-varying phase on the optical pulse. Using dispersion, where optical frequencies travel at different speeds within a medium, we map the spectral content of a pulse onto its temporal profile, which allows us to manipulate the spectral phase by application of an appropriate time-varying phase. Generation of a time-varying RF signal that is synchronized with the optical pulse to be manipulated was implemented using the technique of photonic arbitrary waveform generation, so that the RF is synchronized with the optical signal to be manipulated.

In the project, we were able to successfully generate targeted spectral and temporal phase profiles using PAWG for optical pulses with bandwidths on the order of 20 GHz. This bandwidth limitation is set by the modulator bandwidth and optical dispersion one can achieve with relatively low loss for the pulse to be manipulated. We found that to implement a sequence of distinct temporal and spectral phases presents two main practical challenges. The first issue was associated with difficulties in producing distinct sequential phases using PAWG. This could be addressed by using a high-bandwidth electronic arbitrary waveform generator with a large memory buffer. However, the cost for this equipment was far beyond the budget of the project. The second issue arose from a long time delay arising from the dispersive frequency-to-time mapping followed by temporal-phase modulation to generate spectral phase modulation. To achieve the necessary dispersion, we utilized dispersion compensating fiber of a specified length (typically hundreds of meters), which introduced a significant time delay on the optical signal in addition to stretching out the pulse. This could be remedied by using chirped-fiber Bragg gratings that can apply a specified dispersion without imposing a significant delay. However, this equipment is not readily available and would require custom design and construction. We hope that future temporal mode encoding platforms based on electro-optic phase modulation will benefit from these findings.

Broader Impacts: This project supported the training of one PhD student and one undergraduate student in state-of-the-art quantum optics and quantum information technologies. During the project, the PI has worked with colleagues at the University of Oregon to develop a Quantum Technology Master’s Internship program. This program will train master’s students in quantum information science and technology (QIST) with a direct pipeline into the workforce, filling a major national need for trained scientists in QIST. More broadly, the PI has worked with colleagues in humanities to study the societal impacts of QIST. The PI organized a panel discussion at the Frontiers in Optics Conference, Denver, September 2024 on this topic.
